channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘I Am Stuck Until That Border Opens’: Marooned in Paradise
item.description: This geographically isolated community in Washington State has avoided the coronavirus, but at a considerable cost.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: To reach the rest of the United States from Point Roberts, Wash., requires two international border crossings with a 24-mile drive in between.

item.title: Demonstrators Fear Volatile New Phase in Protests Around Country
item.description: As right-wing groups increasingly move to confront unrest in cities, clashes are breaking out between demonstrators with starkly different views on how to keep cities safe.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker, Julie Bosman and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered in Portland, Ore., as officers watched from patrol vehicles on Sunday. In recent weeks, long-time activists have grown jittery about revving vehicles and unfamiliar faces in the crowds.

item.title: Federal Government Relaxes Rules on Feeding Low-Income Students
item.description: Under pressure from Congress, the Agriculture Department agreed to extend special rules making it easier for schools to provide subsidized meals, but only through December.
item.dc:creator: Kate Taylor
item.media:description: When schools closed their doors in March, the Agriculture Department issued waivers allowing districts to give a free meal to any child 18 or younger.

item.title: Liberty Will Investigate University’s Operations Under Jerry Falwell Jr.
item.description: The board of trustees said an independent forensic firm would look into all facets of Liberty’s operations, including “financial, real estate and legal matters,” while Mr. Falwell was president.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:description: Jerry Falwell Jr., who had served as Liberty’s president and chancellor since 2007, resigned last week in the wake of a sex scandal.

item.title: Homeland Security Blocked Warnings of Russian Campaign Against Biden
item.description: The department’s leaders declined to publish a memo that describing Russian attempts to question Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s health, prompting new scrutiny of political influence at the department.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Russian state media agencies were posting “allegations about the poor mental health” of Joseph R. Biden Jr., a July 9 intelligence bulletin warned.

item.title: Five Questions Democrats Anxiously Want Answered
item.description: Are the polls tightening? Aren’t the polls wrong anyway? Why hasn’t Biden been doing more? What if Trump throws the results into chaos? How is the presidential election still two months away?
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer

item.title: At the State Dept., Calling for Alliances and Acting as a Coalition of One
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the U.S. wants multilateralism “to actually work.” Then he issued a series of unilateral sanctions and other punishments against Trump administration adversaries.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced new limits on Chinese diplomats during a news conference in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Cheap, widely available steroid drugs were shown to reduce the risk of death in some patients.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Court Rules Guantánamo Detainees Are Not Entitled to Due Process
item.description: The decision in the case of a Yemeni held at the military prison in Cuba since 2004 found that an indefinite detainee’s only constitutional right is to challenge his detention.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: A detainee at Guantánamo Bay. The court’s decision may have implications for the 9/11 trial at Guantánamo.

item.title: Amtrak Will Furlough Over 2,000 Workers Because of the Coronavirus
item.description: The job cuts come as the rail agency’s response to fiscal challenges receives scrutiny from rail advocates and federal lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Amtrak employee at Union Station in Washington, D.C. Ridership on relatively shorter routes like those in the Northeast Corridor is down more than 80 percent.

item.title: How a Smooth Election in Massachusetts Could Be a Cautionary Tale
item.description: Election experts said that Tuesday’s primary offered a mix of smart policies and harsh deadlines, and that the state benefited from not having a highly charged political atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: More than 760,000 absentee ballots that arrived by mail were prepared, processed and ready to be counted on Election Day in Massachusetts.

item.title: Trump Administration Will Redirect $62 Million Owed to World Health Organization
item.description: The money, part of $120 million owed in annual dues, will go to other agencies fighting flu and buying vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:description: World Health Organization headquarters in Geneva. U.N. members are obliged to give a year’s notice of withdrawal and pay all dues owed.

item.title: New Treatment for Lou Gehrig's Disease Shows Promise
item.description: A study of their therapy and clinical trials of other experimental treatments are offering glimmers of hope that paralysis from the disorder can be slowed.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.category: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke
item.media:credit: Aileen Perilla for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mike Teal, who lives in Tallahassee, began developing symptoms of A.L.S. in 2016. He takes an experimental drug called AMX0035 which aims to slow the progression of the disease.

item.title: U.S. government debt soars near levels not seen since immediately after World War II.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley

item.title: Joni Ernst, in Close Senate Race, Repeats a Debunked Coronavirus Theory
item.description: The Iowa senator’s comments echoed a false claim, spread by President Trump over the weekend, that deaths from Covid-19 have been inflated.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Joni Ernst at a news conference after a Senate Republicans luncheon in June in Washington.

item.title: Backed by Federal Funds, New Virus Tests Are Hitting the Market
item.description: Six months into the pandemic and with no coherent national testing strategy, the Trump administration is encouraging private development of an array of faster and cheaper techniques.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere and Katherine J. Wu
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Christopher Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses preparing to test a patient for the coronavirus in Liberty, Mo., last month. The stimulus bill allocated $2.5 billion to support testing.

item.title: CDC Tells States How to Prepare for Covid-19 Vaccine by Early November
item.description: As President Trump pushes the possibility of a vaccine this year, the C.D.C. has outlined technical scenarios to state public health officials for an unidentified Vaccine A and Vaccine B.
item.dc:creator: Sheila Kaplan, Katherine J. Wu and Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Henry Ford Health System/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A volunteer received an experimental coronavirus vaccine made by Moderna Therapeutics in Detroit last month.

item.title: Trump’s new coronavirus adviser has questioned masks and alarmed government scientists.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland, Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Scott Atlas is promoting a new tack in the White House coronavirus strategy.

item.title: Americans see their rights to protest threatened, a poll finds, and some Republicans are less troubled by that.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Kenosha, Wis., on Tuesday.

item.title: Hans A. Linde, Iconoclastic Legal Scholar, Dies at 96
item.description: As a justice on the Oregon Supreme Court, he was a proponent of the new judicial federalism of the 1970s, which grounded civil rights protections in state constitutions.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak

item.title: Visitors to antifa.com are redirected to Biden’s website. His campaign is not happy.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Davey Alba
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anti-fascist demonstrators at a protest in Washington last year.

item.title: Is it Safe to Send Your Kids to School?
item.description: The toughest call for parents
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
item.media:description: Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan

item.title: Melania Trump Reportedly Used Her Private Email for Government Business
item.description: Stephanie Winston Wolkoff, who served as Mrs. Trump’s senior adviser, told The Washington Post that the first lady also used encrypted messaging apps like Signal to conduct government business.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Melania and Me: The Rise and Fall of My Friendship with the First Lady (Book)
item.media:description: The first lady, Melania Trump, last week after delivering a speech in the Rose Garden during the Republican National Convention.

item.title: Ho, Ho, Hum: Struggling Retailers Brace for a Muted Holiday Season
item.description: September may seem early to be thinking about the holiday shopping season, but retailers are already acknowledging that it will be transformed in fundamental ways.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari and Gillian Friedman
item.category: International Brotherhood of Real Bearded Santas

item.title: Sanders Says Trump Joked About Her ‘Taking One for the Team’ With Kim Jong-un
item.description: Sarah Huckabee Sanders writes in a new book that after Mr. Kim winked at her, President Trump joked that “you’re going to North Korea,’’ “your husband and kids will miss you, but you’ll be a hero to your country!”
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.category: Speaking for Myself: Faith, Freedom, and the Fight of Our Lives Inside the Trump White House (Book)
item.media:description: Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the former White House press secretary, was heavily criticized for her spin on behalf of her boss from the White House podium, often accused of relaying exaggerations or outright falsehoods.

item.title: The owner of a damaged Kenosha business rejected Trump’s photo op. So the White House used the ex-owner.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Rode III, left, the former owner of Rode's Camera Shop, met with President Trump in Kenosha, Wis., on Tuesday.

item.title: A new Monmouth poll shows a tightening race in Pennsylvania.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: Supporters of Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Pittsburgh on Monday. Pennsylvania is a critical swing state.

item.title: Biden and Trump Unveil Dueling Law-and-Order Ads as Both Eye Swing States
item.description: The Biden ad, part of a $45 million one-week television and digital purchase that is by far the campaign’s largest to date, comes as the Democratic nominee pushes back against President Trump’s attacks.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. has repeatedly accused President Trump of stoking divisions and has laid blame for chaos on the current occupant of the White House.

item.title: As virus cases spike in Iowa, Joni Ernst spreads a debunked theory of inflated death figures.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa seemed to echo a false claim spread by President Trump, whose remarks were removed by Twitter for violating rules against disinformation.

item.title: Bat Got Into Your House? Here's What to Do
item.description: “Bats are like people: They panic and can’t calm down,” a researcher said. Here’s how you can help safely evict your unexpected visitor.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele
item.media:description: Bats can squeeze into tiny crevices. Three-quarters of an inch is enough for two bats, which like to congregate in tight spaces to conserve heat and protect themselves from predators.

item.title: As Trump attacks voting by mail, his campaign tells supporters to request absentee ballots.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: Vote-by-mail ballots in sorting trays at an election office in Renton, Wash., on August 5.

item.title: Scientists Report Steroids Can Be Lifesaving for Covid-19 Patients
item.description: New data in hand, the W.H.O. recommended that doctors give the drugs to critically ill patients worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A Covid-19 patient in Sanaa, Yemen. Researchers said steroids should be a first-line treatment to tamp down the body’s immune response in severely ill patients.

item.title: Police Shooting in L.A. Draws an Outcry
item.description: Wednesday: Sheriff’s deputies shot and killed a Black man in South Los Angeles.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A memorial on Tuesday in Los Angeles, at the location where Dijon Kizzee was shot and killed the previous day by Los Angeles County Sheriff's deputies.

item.title: The C.D.C. has ordered a moratorium on evictions for most renters.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein and Jacey Fortin
item.media:description: The Trump administration announced an order on Tuesday to bar evictions of renters for the rest of the year.

item.title: As Trump visited Kenosha, he struggled to stay on message.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump doubled down on a baseless claim about Joseph R. Biden Jr. as he departed for Kenosha, Wis., on Tuesday.

item.title: Ed Markey held off Joseph Kennedy in a Democratic Senate clash in Massachusetts.
item.description: The result was the first loss by a Kennedy in a Massachusetts election and demonstrated the progressive energy that is reshaping the Democratic Party.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Andy Newman
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Edward J. Markey built a strong coalition among young progressives through his support for the Green New Deal.

item.title: Health care powered Democratic victories in 2018. The party hopes for a repeat.
item.description: With the pandemic highlighting the importance of health coverage, Democrats are leaning into health care as a campaign issue. Republicans appear to be on shakier footing.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kaplan
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. discussed protecting the Affordable Care Act during a June appearance in Lancaster, Pa.

item.title: Russians are again targeting Americans with disinformation, Facebook and Twitter warn.
item.description: The companies said the F.B.I. had warned them that a so-called troll farm in St. Petersburg set up a network of fake user accounts and a website.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Facebook and Twitter said on Tuesday that they had taken down a Russian disinformation campaign.

item.title: This is Democrats’ doomsday scenario for election night.
item.description: What if returns in key swing states on Nov. 3 show President Trump ahead, and he declares victory before heavily Democratic mail-in ballots, which he has falsely linked with fraud, are fully counted?
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election workers in Miami-Dade County in Florida processed mail-in ballots for the state’s primary election last month. Polling suggests that significantly more Democrats plan to vote by mail in November.

item.title: Trump Gets a Mixed Welcome in Kenosha
item.description: In Massachusetts, Ed Markey held off Joe Kennedy: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Trump, Unbound
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on Tuesday.

item.title: Covid-19 Live Updates and Tracker
item.description: A Minnesota man is the first person known to have died of Covid-19 after attending the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally. Silvio Berlusconi, Italy’s former prime minister, tested positive for the virus.

item.title: Biden Faults Trump Over Schools’ Inability to Reopen
item.description: On Wednesday, Joe Biden put a spotlight on President Trump’s handling of the pandemic, saying if the president and his administration “had done their jobs early on with this crisis, America’s schools would be open.”
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. held a briefing with education and health experts in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday.

item.title: ‘They Stand on the Shoulders of Giants’: The Next Generation to March on Washington
item.description: Many protesters came to inspire their children and pass down a legacy of action against racial injustice.
item.dc:creator: Ike Edeani and Zach Montague

item.title: World War II After 75 Years: Beyond the War We Know
item.description: We set out to explore the end of the conflict and its aftermath, focusing on lesser-known stories both personal and profound.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Health Care Powered Democratic Wins in 2018. The Party Hopes for a Repeat.
item.description: With the pandemic highlighting the importance of health coverage, Democrats are leaning into health care as a campaign issue. Republicans appear to be on shakier footing.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kaplan
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. discussed protecting the Affordable Care Act during a June appearance in Lancaster, Pa.

item.title: Natural History Museum Brushes Up for a Reopening
item.description: The American Museum of Natural History is going for an intimate experience — allowing hundreds, not thousands, of visitors in per hour — when it reopens on Sept. 9.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Amy Lombard

item.title: ‘That Kept Us Going’: Small Businesses Stay Alive With Local Help
item.description: Cities big and small know they can’t rely on federal stimulus to support their entrepreneurs, so they are finding innovative ways to keep them afloat.
item.dc:creator: Amy Haimerl
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Swikar Patel for The New York Times
item.media:description: A $10,000 city grant helped Giovy Buyers keep her business, Southern Blossom Florist, going in Charlotte, N.C.

item.title: Wildfires Hasten Another Climate Crisis: Homeowners Who Can’t Get Insurance
item.description: Insurers, facing huge losses, have been pulling back from fire-prone areas across California. “The marketplace has largely collapsed,” an advocate for counties in the state said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: The Ranch Fire in Azusa, Calif., east of Los Angeles, in August. Several years of brutal fire seasons have hit insurers hard.

item.title: Melting Glaciers Are Filling Unstable Lakes. And They’re Growing.
item.description: A census of the world’s glacial lakes shows there are more than there used to be, and their water volume is growing.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Kornei
item.media:description: A glacial lake at the end of the Rhone Glacier, near Gletsch, Switzerland.
